sp.p: And of complexion ſanguine, I know it by my dreams.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.l: The roſe-buds now are blooming on your cheekes,
And ope themſelves into a crimſon bluſh;
This haire curles up like wire, and and ſpeakes you luſty,
Your ſtrength is bold, and daring.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Belleeve it, I'me a wanton.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: Come let's to a wench then.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Hang marrying, t'is a ſlavery!

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: A meere purgatory!

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: An hell to be bounde to one, and ſhee prove falſe, ugly, or loude, when wee may enjoy our liberties, to take or leave 'em, as our ſtomack ſerves us; have the choice beautyes runne into our armes, and every night a freſh one.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Hey! to a Wench; to a Wench! capers! now an I were King it ſhould bee treaſon for any ſubject to marry.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: Allow 'em but Wenches, and t'will be well enough.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Or to lye with a Woman.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: How would you doe for ſubjects then?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Perhaps an I had a minde to't, Ide get all my ſubjects my ſelfe, ha! what ſayſt thou to't, Grutti?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: I ſay t'is fit, you have a minde.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Bentivoglio! wee are friends, come thou ſhalt along with us, to a wench, old trangdido, to a wench, and thou ſhalt ſo bumfiddle her.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Nay, good my Lord, touch no more upon that ſtring; but d'ee heare? I came to carry you to one.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Art right? art right? old boy! theſe Phyſitians are notable jerkers, come, where's their rendez-vous?

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: In my Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha? how many?—how many?—whats that there?

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: A draught to provoke.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: —Sleepe.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Nay good Bentivoglio give it mee, a whole one, a whole one!

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Be moderate; you'le take the next beggar you meete elſe; & then the Ladyes expectation yonder will be fruſtrate.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha! ha! he! Super naculum! my old bully lively, my authentick Don, ſoule of pleaſure; line of life; let's too't; ſuch a violent fit o'th ſudden! a dozen Calentures are an ague to't; twenty Juleps will not coole one wiſh.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Let's have him to bed quickly, and b'ele him warme; Bonum erit ſi ſudaverit,

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Foh! his breath ſtinkes oth Univerſity.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Signior tis not perfum'd: —now will I goe fetch theſe Ladyes to him; & if he have courage enough but to ſpeak to 'em; I'le forfeit my art, and turne tooth-drawer.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: A noyſe within of claſhing of Swords, ſome cry, treaſon! treaſon. Enter Urſini, and Valenzo fighting.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: My Lord! —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Villaine!

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: The injury! I am not any way conſcious.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Traytor thou lyeſt;
Hell, and thy ſelfe the greater miſchiefe, has
Conſpir'd to ruine goodneſſe. —

div.stage: Enter the Guard with Piero, they ſeize on Valenzo. & excunt.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Madame! y'have view'd theſe gardens;—has not art
Sweetely conſpir'd with nature, to make up
A pleaſure of variety?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: It takes exceedingly.—

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What do's?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Pretty indeede,
To have theſe flowers reade morall lectures to us.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Yet Madame, you can finde in your heart to treade
Them underfoote, ſcorning as much the beauty,
As the rare ſenſe they cary.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Yes I can,
Yet ſtreight I turne, and plucke 'em; —binde 'em up,
In one faire volume, thus —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And what reade you, pray?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: The emblemes of true vertues in each leafe,
Imprinted there, at natures proper charges.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What thinke you of this Lilly?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: It figures innocence.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Weare it in your boſome.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Innocence indeed
Should be the breaſts faire individuall mate.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: It will become you well.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: So will this crowne Imperiall your head,
Pray ſtick it there.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.l: I ſhould be the envie of the Court then,
T'is a pretty flower, what think you if I carry it to the Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: Fit, very apt and fit, lady, — as fit
A gift, as this were for a Lord, an hony-ſuckle,
The amorous woodbindes off-ſpring; it emblemes love;

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: You would not have us make love?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: This myſticke way has bin allow'd of;

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And practis'd?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Yes, and practis'd.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sure I ſhould never do't.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: No Madame? why are not men creatures
As worthy Courtſhip, as wee?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Oh! but we are women!

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Oh! but we are proud.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Shall I take't on your experience?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Or your owne:— hal whoſe voyce is that?

l.hi: My heart is big with griefe, my wombe with luſt,
Both fruits of my too eaſie truſt;
Breake firſt my heart, and it will be
The welcomſt, and moſt ſafe delivery.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Hence my delight! thou art turn'd traytour to mee:
Thy ſtrings convey'd a poyſon to my eares,
And they dranke deeply of it;— yet forbeare,
Alas it was my ſelfe, my inward griefe,
Throwne from the ſoule in often ſighs, that made
Thy ſound infectious; 'tis with that as guilt,
It growes ſtill greater as 'tis borne about,
And poyſons every thing ſhould worke it's cure.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Is not this Sylvio, Calantha's Page?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: A lover growne? las pretty innocence.
How finely ſorrow ſhewes there — ! That, that paſſion
Is well expreſl't; now ſigh, then knock the breaſt. Excellent.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Let's uſe the benefit of this ſhade, to hide
Our ſelves, and ſecretly acquainted grow
With the blacke ſtorie of his ſad miſhap.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: How has thy name, thy ſelfe, thy friend deceiv'd thee!
That onely wert acquainted with the ſound
Of happineſſe; mock't with a falſe report,
Into a reall miſery; whoſe eaſie nature
(The greateſt foe unto it ſelfe, was flatter'd)
Out of a virgin treaſure; and then left
Rifled of all; but (what griefe now is preying on)
A hapleſſe life — yet cruell theefe, th'aſt left
So much of thee behind, as ſhall hereafter
Tell to the world a darke and gloomy tale
Of thy blacke perjury.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Ha! do's he riddle,
Or play with griefe?

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: No 'tis too like a truth.

sp.speaker: Sylv.
sp.l: Me thinkes each thing
I meete withall upbraids my fond credulity;
The ſoaring larke hovers aloft i'th aire,
At diſtance from th'inchanting glaſſe, that Courts
Her to her ruine! the fearefull Quaile
Suſpects and ſhuns the muſicke of the pipe
That ſings her into fetters.
Onely poore I am ſillier than theſe;
Witneſſe th'untimely ſwelling of this wombe
Pregnant to my diſgrace;— As I lay hid
In yonder thicket, the brambles gently ſwell'd,
And hid my ſhame, which yet each triviall winde
But dallying with, perſwaded from my covert!
And left mee naked to heaven's eye; the boughs
Of the next willow clung about my head,
As if they'd knit themſelves into a garland,
Which I ſhould weare for my forſaken lover,—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Very pretty!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Wer't not ſo ſad.

sp.speaker: Sylv:
sp.l: Oh you the weake ſupporters of my woes,
Why do'e faile mee now at greateſt need?
Beare mee at leaſt into ſome hollow cave
Where I may die, free from an after ſcorne;
And not when I am dead, be found the ſhame
Of our fraile ſex;— Oh! I faint, and fall,
Juſt like the early branches of ſome tree,
Whoſe haſty ſap ſhootes into early fruit,
Till the o're laden boughs cracke with the weight,
Ere yet they bee full ripe —

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: I am amaz'd, a woman!

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Some Lady here o'th Court, I'le lay my life on't;
Let's to the Princeſſe and informe her of it.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: Ferrando. Ʋrſini. (Valenzo, Piero, with guard about them.)

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: —Let mee eternally periſh to honour,
If their heads anſwer not for this foule inſolence.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: Though't be a ſin of that portentous bulke,
That 'tſtartles all the gods, and juſtice ſelfe
Wakes from a long dead lethargie to meete it:
Yet Kings are great as they, and ſpight of fate
Or rigorous lawes, may triumph in their mercy.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Away with 'em to execution;
Him, and his fellow murderer, away:
—Pardon a Traytour?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Though you might urge, 'twere treaſon of that height,
That none but they could thinke of, much leſſe act:
That murder cries for murder, blood for blood:
That he whoſe innocence they ſacrific'd
To their mad fury, was your loyall ſubject;
This on your marriage day — to affront Hymen.
And when your nuptiall torch burnt brighteſt, dead it
With bloud, into a ſickly glimmmering taper:
That they ſhould dare aſſault me! — i'th' Court —
One whom your goodneſſe has bin pleaſ'd to looke
Into a life, and honours, plac't i'th' ſtate,
Only to interpoſe my ſelfe betweene,
And meet all dangers that are ſhot at you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twas a murder
Intended on our perſon, but that Heaven —

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Was juſt in the prevention; True it might be ſo,
And were it, yet upon ſubmiſſion
Such faults have beene remitted.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Away with 'em, I'le heare no more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Downe holy anger! —
One word, and I'me gone— you are my Soveraigne,
And there's divinitie worne in that title,
Which I adore, and thinke my ſelfe as happy
In this ſo early doome, ſince you are pleaſ'd with't,
As heaven had ſpoke it; though not till old age,
When nature claim'd it as a due! Yet Sir
Be gentle to my memory; and if
At any time my crimes appeare before you,
Freſh in your thought, to ſtaine my Heraldrie,
The happy mention of my vertuous acts,
From ſome that love my duſt, ſhall riſe to pleade
My innocence—; and may you never live
To curſe th' untimely hand; or houre that rob'd you
Of ſo much loyaltie!— for you Ʋrſini—
If ere your name ſhall fall in mention, when
I come i'th other world, expect me not
Your friend; I feare me, I ſhall tell ſad tales
In th'eares of heaven;—Farewell —

div.stage: Exeunt Val. Pier. with a guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Impudent Traytour!

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Yet ſtill I dare be good; and ſpight of all
His hate, or malice to me, thus ſtand up
To begge his life.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Not after ſo much injury?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Yes, if Valenzo dare be ſinfull ſtill
In wrongs, it ſhall be call'd my piety
To ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Th'art all goodneſſe;—for thy ſake
Wee'le mixe ſome mercy with our doome,
He that ſubmits firſt to thee, has his pardon,
See juſtice done on th'other; this ſentence
Shall ſtand irrevocable;—

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Plague to your eaſie nature! —
Ha! this 'tis to over-act; how have I almoſt fool'd my ſelf, out
Of my owne plots;
I were in a fine caſe now, if Piero
Should not accepta life on this condition.
I'le ſend to him—Caſſio! Grutti! who waites there? —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ladies, pray abſent your ſelves a while; —
— With child? impudent whore! to what curſ'd lumpe
Have thy ſinnes ſwolne thee?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Oh, me miſerable!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hence ingrate wretch! that haſt abuſ'd my favours
So farre, till thou haſt made a ſin of charitie:
— Ha! doſt weepe? —
My rare diſſembler! thoſe teares which art hath taught
To flow, carry more ſinfull cunning in 'em,
Then thoſe the flattering Syrens weare upon
Their cheekes, when they court man to ruine:
Yet tell me ere you goe, whom have thoſe lookes
Beguil'd, and train'd into your ſinfull armes.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: You muſt prepare your ſelfe for a ſad ſtory then:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes, like enough, a tale as ſad, and diſmall
As that of Troy, and as much truth in't too!
Quickly, diſpatch, before my anger prove
Too maſculine!—and be modeſt in'th relation.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: You'le wiſh't untold.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Undone I doe! but why
This tedious circumſtance? it do's involve
Your guilt.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Know then, that when I was my ſelfe
My name was—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Alberto's daughter?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Yes his—that was once Alberto
Durazzo's farre-fam'd Marqueſſe; till
His cruell Maſter ſeiz'd on's life, and honours,
At his returne from Sicily i'th firſt warres;
Where he receiv'd a fatall overthrow.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He was in action bold, and valiant!
However fortune wrought him this diſgrace;

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Here! here began my miſery.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Proceede, truſt me I now begin to pitty thee.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Then let me die without your farther knowledge
Of my miſhap; t'will be injurious
Unto my aſhes, and diſturbe their quiet;
I know it will;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Nay, prithee tell me, come, and I'le weepe with thee.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You'le have cauſe enough ere I've done;
Therefore don't hear't;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Is there ought in't concernes me?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Too much

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nay, then I muſt, and will have all the ſtory,
Or thinke thee a foule proſtitute.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: 'Tis thus then!
—Yet do'nt beleeve me, ſay that I was mad,
Diſtracted with my ſorrowes, that my words
Fell ſo uneven from me, you miſtooke
The ſenſe; ſay any thing.—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Come, come, I know thou wilt tell truth!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Or may I never finde peace hereafter!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How I feare
Whether this ſtory tends?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The King Madame.
Ferrando;—(Seize me Courteous death,
Or I ſhall poyſon all her joyes;)

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha! what of him?
Be ſudden, or, I ſweare by my juſt anger,
I'le ſtreight rip up the cradle of thy luſt,
The den where all thy looſe adultery's
Were acted; ſearch each corner of thy wombe.
That keepes a record of thy villanyes!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Ferrando was the author of my fall:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: More lying then that evill Genius
That wrought the firſt mans fall!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Ferrando! oh! oh! (Swoons)

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou rebell paſſion jealouſy! what mean'ſt thou
To tumult in my breaſt?—ha! yet why not?
Why may not he be falſe?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: T'is ſo!—Felicia!—ſhe's gone, ſhe's gone!
Helpe there, Florinda! Violetta! Ladyes!
Soe—ſhe begins to breath;—looke up Felicia!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Here,—a medall? this confirmes it;
sp.stage: finds a me dall about her necke with the pict: of Fer: & Fel. in it
sp.l: Ferrando and Felicia!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Ha! the Princeſſe!
Beſhrew me but I've had a fearefull dreame!
I hope t'was but a dreame;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No; I know all,
Ferrando's falſe, as ſtayn'd with ſin, and perjury
As howling-Ghoſts.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Good Madame don't affright me;
Your fancy's darke and gloomy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes all hell
Is there at worke contriving a revenge;

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Revenge? for whom?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No matter whom;—But tell me
How, and with what falſe othes, he won thee firſt
To his looſe ſheets.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I'le tell you; but you firſt
Shall promiſe me, to breade no other way
To your revenge and mine, then I ſhall leade you in.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I doe:
Let's ſir, and heare it all.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Whilſt yet Alberto liv'd
As great in favour as in bloud, the glory
O'th Court of Naples, honour'd with dayly viſits
From his Prince; t'was my unhappy deſtiny,
(Foole that I was to be ſo credulous!)
To receive many favours from Ferrando;
Which I interpreted i'th way of love;
Meane while, this match was treated of betweene
Him, and your ſelfe; your Father (Sicily's King)
After your plighted troths, and formall ceremonyes
Us'd betwixt Prince, and Prince, would breake it off,
Which caus'd a ſudden warre upon his Country;
In which expedition Alberto
Was ſent chiefe generall: the King being fore't
Now to withdraw his publick viſits, imploy'd
Ʋrſini in the buſineſſe; gets acceſſe
Privately to me i'th might, and that too
Allwayes i'th darke, leſt happily he might
Be knowne to any of my ſervants; Briefly
After his many oathes, and proteſtations
Of his faire meaning, I at laſt conſented
To let him ſteale the fruit, he durſt not owne:
When ere I urg'd, he was ingug'd to you,
He anſwer'd, that was but a tricke of ſtate,
A faire pretence to colour his deſigne;
And mak't ſeeme glorious, in the eye o'th world;
That he warr'd for a Kingdome, not a Queene;
Onely intreated me, that I'de be ſilent,
And not ſo much as in a ſigne betray
To'th day, what onely night was conſcious of.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: You condiſcended?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Willingly.
My father i'th meane while returnes defeated,
For which the King led on by paſſion, ſeiz'd
His life and honours, theſe conferr'd on his
Now favourite Ʋrſini: the fleete re inforc't,
He himſelfe the ſecond time in perſon
Went generall of the forces, conquer'd Sicily,
And ſlew your father on Meſſina's plaines,
Laſt brought you away captive.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But how cam'ſt thou to Court in Sicily?
Thou told'ſt another ſtory then:

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: For that
I crave your pardon, 'twas all the untruths
My life has ere bin charg'd with; but 'twas thus:
Led partly by a jealous feare, to ſee
What he intended; partly to find out
My brother Frederico, who was left there
Commander in Mazara, which was tooke
In the firſt expedition, in this diſguiſe,
'Mongſt others whom deſire of fame, or profit
Led to your ſhore, I croſſ't the ſeas; but failing
In queſt of him I ſought, I came to Court,
Where ſince I have remain'd.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But why Felicia
Did'ſt not diſcloſe thy ſelfe before this time,
Now things are growne ſo bad?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: When firſt I ſaw
Your perſon, and how mutually you lov'd,
Knowing how farre I was beneath your worth,
So deare I held you both, that I determin'd
For ever to be loſt to memory;
And ſerve you thus in this diſguiſe: which I
Had done, but that this hapleſſe chance
Betray'd mee to your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Alas! thy piety has undone us both!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: 'Twas my too cruell deſtinies!

sp.speaker: Cal,
sp.l: Methinkes wee two now ſeeme to be ſet copies
Of griefes, to which wrong'd virgins will repaire,
To take out patternes by.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Our wrongs and ſorrowes
Have made us juſt ſo like to one another,
That each ſeemes th'o others counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: We'le ſit, and deſcant on our miſeries,
Count the extent of each, proportion teares,
And ſighs unto them.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Her's that doth ſurmount,
Shall borrow griefe of t'other.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: H'as robb'd mee of a father cruell Tyrant,

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: H'as robb'd mee of a father cruell Tyrant,

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Bereav'd mee of my friends, and loving ſubjects,

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: Bereav'd mee of my Brother, and my friends.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Tane away all my honours, and my dower.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: Taken my virgin honour, all my dower.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: H'as mock't mee with the title of a Queene.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.p: H'as mock't mee with the title of a Queene.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: —But I am loſt in Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Sylv:
sp.p: And I am loſt in Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Felicia come, and as our wrongs are equall,
So let our revenge be; we'le hand in hand
Aſſault this Tyrant; and in bloody Characters
Print on his body the ſtory of our ſufferings:

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: Yet this cannot cure our griefe.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: What though, wrong'd innocence?
In death it will intitle us to honours;
And though our bodies moulder to corruption,
Our better part ſhall ſurvive fame; our names,
Free from decay, ſhall ſwell up numerous volumes;
Whil'ſt our ſad legends ſhall be made a pillow,
To every ſleeping virgin.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: O yet for my ſake have ſome pitty on him,
And for that part of him, that's cradled here,
'Las he may live to make us faire amends.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: For thy ſake I could ſpare him, but my wrongs
Sit heavy here, and urge mee to revenge.

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: But ſay l've thought a way, how we may yet
Be both reſtor'd to happineſſe, would you not
Accept, and follow't?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Speake it (gentle ſoule.)

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.l: As yet (you know) your virgin treaſure ſtands
Free from his ruder touch: thoſe Ceremonies,
Which link't you in one Hymeneall knot,
Religion will make void, the praecontract
'Twixt him and mee being knowne, ſo that you then,
On this part are free from him; enjoy him thus
You cannot, neither would you (I ſuppoſe)
After theſe wrongs, (if you might be permitted:)
What hinders then, but that I take your place
This night? and ſhew him, to what height his perjury
Has wrought our wrongs, whilſt you in ſome diſguiſe
May quit the Court, and e're next Sun appeare,
From hence towards France, to whom you are allyed
In blood, and wrongs. —

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Content, — I'le in, and haſte mee to be gone,
To goe there is ſome hope.

sp.speaker: Syl:
sp.p: To ſtay there's none.

div.head: SCEN. I.
div.stage: Piero. Caſſio. as in the Priſon.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: —To mee this?

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.l: Out of particular reſpect
Hee ſtood ingag'd to repay your merits.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Dare you
Promiſe ſo much for's Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.l: The Contents
Of that will ſpeake, how much he tenders goodneſſe
In every noble breaſt.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: No doubt Sir, but
You are familiar with the ſenſe it carries,
And can informe mee, better than the darke Character.

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.l: 'Tis that you'd be pleas'd t'accept
A life, for which to's Piety you ſhall owe,
Onely a faire acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Wondrous good!
'Tis a becomming charity this, and hee
Weares it amongſt the chiefeſt of his vertues.

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.l: Sir, it muſt needs be eminent in's Lordſhip,
Since exercis'd upon ſo noble a ſubject
As your ſelfe

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: But ſtay? — now I thinke on't,
This is a benefit of that nature, it ſeldome comes
Alone, are there not honours too? preferments
That wait upon this gift? ſpeake, ſhall I be
His Lordſhips creature?

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.p: He's paſſionately yours.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Are we not for deſigne? — ba, what darke tricke
Is there i'th State, that doth imply danger
Enough for us to mannage, doth he thinke
Us fit to temper poyſons, or uſe the benefit
O'th night to ſeize on his State-rivals, are we
Potent enough for faction, or intended
Intelligencer to ſome forraine Prince?

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.p: What meane you?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Ingagements of this nature urge a returne
Of thankes proportionable to themſelves,
And what we have of ſuch rich values,
I cannot tell, leſt t'be our ſoules forfeited
To'th next occaſion his Lordſhip has to uſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.l: This is ſtrange language Sir, my underſtanding
Has not yet arriv'd at what it meanes.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Go home and ſtudy it then:—and do'e heare,
Entreat my Lord, t'employ his favours to
Some further profit, he'le ſcarce be gainer by 'em elſe.

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.p: I ſhall acquaint him with your humour.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Do maggot, wriggle, wriggle, do:—

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. II.
div.stage: To Piero, Charintha; (Valenzo behinde the hangings.)

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Madame! I am all joy, life, honours,
Preferment, and what not?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Then I'me undone!
Piero! didſt not promiſe me to ſtand
The utmoſt of's temptations? didſt thou boaſt
Thy vertuous ſtrength, and fall'ſt at the firſt onſet?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Life Madame is ſweet.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: If hitherto
It hath bin ſo, hereafter t'will be all
Bitterneſſe, thou haſt betray'd thy friend to death;
The thought of which will ſoure all thy content,
Make thy beſt pleaſures relliſh worſe then gall.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Life, with the worſt that can befall us, is
A good exchange for death; but here are honours
Annex't to't Lady! I ſhall be great in favour.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Thou wilt grow big in ſinne too! thou muſt barter
Thy vertue for preferment; which being gone,
At beſt thou't be but painted ruines,
A glorious miſery; thou muſt owe life
To him, that will infect and kill thy ſoule.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Yet you would be content, Valenzo ſhould
Accept a life, on this condition.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yet he may live, and ſtill be vertuous.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Why? ſo may I.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yet he's thy friend.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Am not I his too?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: T'will be a glory to thee after death
That thou wert friendſhips martyr, a title
Will ſit upon thy tombe, richer than all
Thy Heraldry; more laſting than thy marble.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: To ſhew how farre, I can preferre him to
My ſelfe, I am content this honour ſhould be his.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Falſe to thy friend, and vertue! that onely cam'ſt
To mocke calamitie, and midſt our wrongs
Remaine our greateſt in jurie.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Miſtake mee not,
I onely did prepare you for a joy,
Which now you're ripe for:—know then, 'T return'd
Him ſcorne for all his flattering promiſes;
And ſtood reſolv'd t'incounter with his fury,
Made hot by my diſdaine.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Miracle of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Since 'tis decreed that one of us muſt fall,
And onely one, my death ſhall free us both
From the lawes rigour, enjoy your beſt Valenzo,
Enjoy him long, may you (a happy paire)
Grow like two neighbouring roſes on one ſtalke,
Partaking mutually each others ſweetes;
Whence no rude hand approach to raviſh you,
But when you are full blowne, and ripe for heaven,
May you fall gently both into one grave,
There lye intomb'd in your owne odours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Piero, thou go'ſt
To heaven, to be the envy of the Saints;
For when thou com'ſt where thoſe bleſt troopes reſide,
No man ſhall ere direct a vow, or prayer,
But unto thee! — Valenzo take thy friend, (Val: Enters)
Take him unto thy boſome, he has ſo much
Of heaven in him, I feare he can ſcarce die.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: Is it your feare, Madame? can he deſerve leſſe in
Your faire opinion, than to be thought immortall?
That death at length ſhould boaſt a victory
O're ſo much goodneſſe. — Methinkes (Piero)
Thou ſhould'ſt for ever ſtand a rich example,
To all mankind, who in thy fall will ſicken,
And dye to vertue; injoy the happineſſe
Of thine owne fate; I will not rob thee of
One precious minute; live till time has powr'd
A reverend ſnow upon thy head.—

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: But juſtice muſt be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: I'le bow my ſelfe beneath the ſtroake.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: To ſlay
The innocent, is not to expiate,
But make a crime, preſerve thy ſelfe entire
To thy Charintha, King, and Country.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: What!
And betray my friend to death?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: To what
I have deſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: T'was thy too forward zeale, and a ripe ſpirit.
That ſpur'd thee on to action, thou didſt it for
Thy friend, for mee, and had not juſtice bin
Wrong'd in't, the honour had bin mine, why not
The ſhame?

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: You muſt not, ſhall not die.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: No more!
'Twill prove a breach of friendſhip elſe, I muſt not,
Shall not die: my honour ſuffers double,
Thou wouldſt foyle mee both in love, and valour.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Pitty theſe teares.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Or in thy ruine I
Am loſt.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.l: Juſtice requires but one, her fate
Is ſo involv'd in yours, you cannot fall,
But in it ſhee muſt finde a certaine death;
Thinke then, how can you ſatisfie the law?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farre eaſier than you, in whoſe ſad loſſe
The whole world ſuffers, and in thy untipe fall
Looſes all goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Stint this pious ſtrife,
I have bin too much woman, and betrai'd
My name to infamy, in this tame paſſion:
Poſſeſſe mee a juſt anger, a ſpirit great
And noble as my birth; that I may ſhake,
And rowze this ſleepy Prince, from his dull lethargie;
Who's wholy loſt, in the bewitching flatteries
Of that bad man;— alas this is a danger
Too potent for your ſtarres to free you from;
Henceforth I'le be your deſtinies: for ſince
This calme brings nothing but a certaine fall,
A ſtorme ſhall either ſave, or ruine all.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. III.
div.stage: A Table is ſet forth; taper, pen, inke, &c.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Contemne our pardon.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Returne your favours too
With ſo much ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Better they'd play'd with lightning,
Or hugg'd a thunderbolt.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: Juſtice is ſlow
Of pace, and if not led by furie,
Seldome o'retakes the crime, let your returne
Of puniſhment be quicke, and active, delay is worſe
Than pitty, and more dangerous: Valenzo
Is popular, and who knowes, but hee had rather,
Owe his life to the peoples mutiny, than your pardon,
And therefore ſlighted it.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Oh the ſtate of Princes!
How farre are we from that ſecuritie,
Wee dream't of in th'en pectance of our crowne?
Were forraine dangers nothing, yet we nouriſh
Our ruine in our boſome: Valenzo is a traytour,
So is Piero too; and who is not in this age?
It is unſafe not to ſuſpect our ſelfe.
To torture with 'em; be noble in thy juſtice:—
Here draw a warrant for their execution; —
We'le ſign't with our owne ſigner;—hence pitty,
Poſt from our breaſt; we baniſh thee our boſome
Th'art a diſeaſe bred there to ruine Majeſtie: Urſini preparing to write.
And ſink us below our ſubjects ſcotue.—

sp.speaker: Charintha?
sp.l: Our Princely couſin, welcome to Court; thou haſt
Beene too long abſent, (I muſt chide thee for't,)
And envy'd us the boaſt of vertue.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Vertue!

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Some malicious devill now, or other,
Has intic'd her from her beads;
To undoe mee, and my plots, ſhee carries anger
In her brow: — this I muſt mitigate, or I am
Loſt. —

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Thou art ſo eager after heaven,
Thou woo't o're-buy thy happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Never fear't Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: But thy devotion's ſeaſon'd with ſo much charity,
Thou pil'ſt a ſtocke of merit up for us
At Court.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: I beleeve y'had need on't.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: As long as we live here we ſhall; —

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: So wicked!

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ha! what frowne's that, whence theſe clouds, Charintha?
So riſes the bluſhing morne, as thou wert wont
To ſmile, when thou appear'dſt, we owe
Our day unto thy eyes; and if thou think'ſt
Thy beautie's worne too cheape, we'le become tributaries
To thee for light; chaſe hence this ſullen darkneſſe,
Thy abſence has already made too long
A night.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: No Sir; 'twas your blacke deeds▪

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How's this?
Do'e know mee, who I am?

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Not well.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Your King.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: A Tyrant
Of bigge, and grorious impietic's,
A regall monſter, the true head of that
Beaſt you rule, the multitude: more cruell
Than enrag'd lyons, or robb'd beares; who both
Will ſpare the innocent, and humble.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Looke to'th Lady there, ſure ſhe's diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: My wrongs indeed would make mee ſo.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: What wrongs? whence? or from whom?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Raiſe not my auger higher with your ſcorne;—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By all that's.—

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Or if't be ignorance of my ſufferings,
It but betrayes your want of reaſon, and
How farre you're loſt to man, by your fond dotage.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Grow more particular, or wonder ruines mee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Good God! I've ſuffer'd ſo long, till patience
Grew my greateſt crime.—

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Now, now the ſtorme is coming this way,
But I'me prepar'd to meete it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Whence? or from whom?
Aske this good man how often he has mourn'd
Over the ruines of my fame? how often
His eares have met with the report of my
Diſgrace? how I was noys'd a ſtrumpet? when
Each talking thing at Court, might freely act
A rape upon my vertue, till I was left
All a whole ſtaine, blacke as the front of perjur'd
Sinners? while you, (as if I'de bin a trifle
Caſt from your blood, and kindred, or ſome darke thing,
Whoſe actions were ſo ſowly bad.
That report better'd 'em in the expreſſion:)
Could ſit as ſilent as the night; as calme
As ſeas, when the windes ſleepe; yet at laſt be juſt;
And ſay, how have I appear'd to you, or him,
That calumnie has thus bin priviledg'd,
To violate my honour?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Madame,
I have allwayes ſpoke you, chaſtities beſt example.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Innocence it ſelfe is not ſo white.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Yet he that would confirme this with his ſword,
Muſt meete, with priſons, wrackes, and tortures,
As a reward of ſo much vertue!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: Sweeteſt Princeſſe! —

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: And ere he die, muſt ſuffer in's honour,
Be proclaim'd traytor to the ſtate:

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ʋrſini, thou haſt abus'd our truſt.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: My Lord.—

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.l: Too weake pretence, for your ingratitude
To ſo large merit; Naples call's him
Her chiefe preſerver; he brought home victory,
By his owne arme atchiev'd, when the proud foe,
Threatned your Kingdome with a fatall downefall.
He, to whoſe arme you owe your life, your crowne,
To whom in warre, you'd ſooner flie for helpe
Then to the Altar; now in peace muſt have
His temples robb'd; his garlands from his brow
Tranſplanted. to adorne this uſeleſſe ſtatua.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: Madame, I have not ſo appear'd in managing theſe affaires of yours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Would thou had'ſt,
Or ſomewhat that carries leſſe reſemblance
Of man: Oh thou art bravely wicked.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: I have not us'd the art to boaſt the vertue
Of mine owne actions; yet heaven knowes
They were all good, and aim'd at ends as honourable
As your deſires.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ʋrſini leave, till there is hope of pardon,
This impudence in ſinne,
Bid's a defiance to all mercy; did we not,
At your perſwaſion, give order for Valenzo's
Quicke diſpatch?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: How ere I ſeem'd (great Sir) to runne downe with the ſtreame of your violent paſſion, yet my intents ſtill bore up againſt it; witneſſe this paper.
sp.stage: Deliver's a paper to Ferrando, who reades it.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ha! What's here a pardon?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: Which you had ſeal'd ere this, had not this Lady here interrupted it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: your paſſion would not have permitted you,
To have o're view'd what you conſented too;
This I knew, as likewiſe how dangerous it
Would have beene to the ſtate, if he had fall'n.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Againe my owne Ʋrſini:—
Charintha, pardon our errours, we will deſerve it,
By the future love, and honours we will throw
On our Valenzo, — here take my ſigner
Fetch 'em to Court.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: You are noble.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ʋrſini Waite on her to the Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: You honour mee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Oh how neere were we deſtruction.
Reaſon ſit ſtill enthron'd in thine owne ſtate,
T'is paſſion onely ruines Kings, not fate.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN: IV.
div.stage: Bentivoglio. Alphonſo. Grutti. Caſſio. Violetta. Florinda.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Hold up, hold up Sir, the Ladies are comming this way,— for ſhame,—God's mee, they'r here; why do'e tremble ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: A violent fit o'th ague; oh! oh! oh! have mee to bed gently, gently, or I ſhall ſcatter all my limbes;

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Diſcredited for ever, (here take this ſtaffe Sir)— have I boaſted your ſtrength to them? — fortifi'd you forth' incounter, and you faile me thus? — undone, undone!

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! for halfe a dozen of night caps.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Here Sir, on with 'em; they'r ſomewhat durty, they'll keepe you the warmer; — now ſhall I be call'd Mountebanke; Quackeſalver, Piſpot-peeper: and all the ugly mangy names can be invented.— come in, come in.—

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: 'Twill be a Scene of modeſt mirth, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: The Phyſitian has cool'd him.

sp.speaker: Bent:
sp.p: Why Sir, you won't diſgrace mee? go towards 'em.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Some fire, ſome fire; —cold, cold, cold, cold.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Here, here, on with my gowne: —this cap, ſo, ſo.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: Ladies, we'le take leave to be bold here to vexe him.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: How do'e my Lord?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: We are come here to await your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: The very thought on't has caſt him into a cold ſweat.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.p: Now for fifty virgins.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: A monopoly of women.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Hey, for a wench, for a wench, to bumfiddle now; Ah! ha!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Oh! ho! oh!

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Do'e remember you'd play the foole in my gowne, and cap excellently.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: Well ſaid Doctour.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: To him Doctour.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Then a noyſe of Muſitians would do rarely.

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.p: Looke he's nodding.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: My Lord you intend no abuſe to us?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Make us hazzard our credits for nothing?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: More clothes; — why hoe there, on my feete I ſay.

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.p: He's dreaming.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Faſt, faſt a ſleepe, ſo, ſo, this charme laſt's till Midnight, and then hee wakes.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: 'Twill be good ſport to ſee him then—

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: Dance up and downe the Court like the ghoſt of old Hippocrates.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: You muſt not expoſe him to the publike view.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: Mr Doctour you're ſufficiently reveng'd, this is enough for you to boaſt on when you come i'th Univerſity.

sp.speaker: Bent.
sp.p: This, and the rare cures I've done upon you two ſhall be my theame.—Good night.— Ladies I'me your ſervant. — My doughty placket-hunter lye thee there, and e'ne awake when thy ſtomacke ſerves thee; to morrow morning I'me for Padua. —

sp.speaker: Ziſc.
sp.l: The night comes on apace, ſtreight every thing
Will be as blacke as I, and alike terrible,
Nay out-doe mee too: each leafe that ſtirres
Affrights the fearfull, makes the guilty tremble,
And yet this night, what is it but a ſhadow?
Yet I am leſſe than that, for I do leſſe:
I that have purpos'd ſo much, act nothing!
Horrour! could but my thoughts be ſeene, they'd owne
Murders, more than the baſiliske could commit,
Were he all eye, more than revenge has acted,
Or than the triviall ſpight of plague, and warre
Produce, in their full heate. — Ʋrſini be ſpeedy
Or I'le outrunne deſigne. —

sp.speaker: Ziſc.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: The houres are favourable
And have brought opportunitie along with 'em,
We muſt reſolve for action.

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.p: I'me prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: But Ziſco, art thou ſure Felicia was.—

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.l: Sure? puh! would you know? I my ſelfe
Am the Moore he caus'd to raviſh her.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: And canſt thou do't againe?

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.p: Bravely.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: This night then thou ſhalt—raviſh his Miſtris,
Calantha! this night! I've prepar'd all things ready
For thy conveyance into her chamber—thou wilt doe't

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.p: Reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: And kill her too?

sp.speaker: Ziſc.
sp.p: An ſhee were my mother.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: Obſcure your ſelfe a while.—how now?

sp.speaker: Grut.
sp.l: My Lord, the French have kept their word,
And uneſpied have ſtolne from Genoa,
Enter'd our haven, and this night have ſet
Upon our fleete, the bold Sicilians too
I'th towne are up in armes.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: There ſpoke my Genius.

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.l: My Lord! the Cittie's in a mutinie,
The Court in wild diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: Well, beyond my hopes: excellent well; Grutti, Caſſio, be nere us, we muſt uſe your helpe to night.

sp.speaker: Caſſ:
sp.l: Valenzo playes from the Caſtle with his Canons,
And ſtrikes both parties without diſtinction:
He's now marching up with a well ord'red troope,
T'is thought he had intelligence of your intents.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: O my fate! that man undoe's mee.
Thus early ſins are blaſted in the bud,
There is no ſafety but in being good.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: —'Tis late.
Each man retire to his quarter: Captaines,
We entertaine your merit with a ſerious welcome.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Our deſerts, my Lord,
Are ſo ſlender, that wer't not to prejudice
Your judgement, we would bluſh to owne any.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Hang this flattery, merit quotha? is't ſuch a piece of merit to cut a ſcore or two of throats; knocke downe an hundred o'th citty herd? a gallant could do ſo much for's Cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: The King ſhall give you each particular thinkes: He owes you both a trophey,

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: His acknowledgement
Of our duty, would raiſe our pride to ſinne,
We ſhould forget to let heaven ſhare i'th victory.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Victories, by Mars's creſt it deſerves not to come i'th Chronicle, though Hollinſhead or Hall, thoſe voluminous forreiners ſhould write our annals, 'twill ne're make us juſtle in among the Caeſars, or owne a name i'th liſt o'th worthies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No Contareno, wee will not have thee painted in vile ugly colours, and clapt upon chimneies, thou ſhalt be cut—

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: In braſſe? mine would make an excellent brazen face?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: In Parian marble, wee'le rob the Quarries
To reare thee up a glorious monument.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: A glorious loame to ſet lazie ſpiders a worke in, an office for birds to mute in, if theſe be your glorious monumēts for men of armes, I'le e'en live to ſin out my merit (as you call it) then when I die, the world and I will ſhake hands, and cry quit of all ſides.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Hee that ſhould heare thee talke thus, and not know
thee well, would doubt thy valour.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Hercules! an hee did he ſhould try it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: T'were puniſhment enough.
Gonçales— I gratulate thy navall victory;
France will have cauſe hereafter to mention thee in ſad ſtory,
Thou giv'ſt them but a churliſh ſalutation.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Such as they deſerv'd,
It ſeemes they came rather to ſteale than fight,
They were as ill prepar'd, as they had meant
To beare our empty hulkes away unqueſtion'd;
For ſoone as they perceived we deſcri'd 'em,
Pale, as the lillies in their trembling flagges,
They turn'd their ſailes, and fled; we made after 'em,
With ſwift wing'd lightning from our Canons mouth,
Which ſunke and fir'd 'em all, ere they could quit
The channell, or gaine the wider Ocean;

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Beleeve mee, noble Souldier, thou art deare
To fame; as old in victory, as in yeares,
Yet ſtill thou toyl'ſt t'undoe thy ſelfe, and benefit
Thy ingratefull ſoyle, which never will be able
To requite thy meaneſt ſervice.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.l: Yet you for the ſame cauſe, i'th pride of youth,
Oppos'd your ſelfe betwixt the ſtate and danger,
When their ſicke hopes, were as their fortunes, deſperate;
Reduc'd a Kingdome to your ſway, in whoſe
Rich ſpoyles, your gawdie Souldier triumphs;
Whilſt boaſting of their rifled plumes, they drinke
Health's to victory; yet thoſe ſo moderate,
Their bowles encreaſe their fury, not their ſurfeits.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: How theſe tall men o'th ſword claw one another?

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: They have an itch of pride runnes through 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Hero's, when thou com'ſt into Elyzium,
To give thee place, ſhall ſhift their bleſſed manſions.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: And load thee with their lawrells.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: How my feares betray mee! ſhunning
One toyle, I runne into another.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Oh mee! I'me ſurpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Cont:
sp.p: Spirit of valour th'art my priſoner.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha! whom have you there?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: (Valenzo! my voyce betrayes mee.)

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: A young Sicilian, ſhall I draw my ſteele,
And give him a gentle ſtroke?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Lend mee my ſword — and be thou what thou wilt I dare thee to thy worſt.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Bravely ſpoke,—ſet forward then.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Traytour! the Princeſſe! Calantha!

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.l: All the better; ſhe's skilfull at her weapon,
We'le but exchange a thruſt in ſport.

sp.speaker: Gal. & Gon.
sp.p: Ha! what meanes this flight?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Dare none of you fight?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Deare Lady, not with you.

sp.speaker: Cal,
sp.l: Then you are cowards, they ſpeake you ſo i'th Citty,
And I came out thus purpoſely to try you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you pleaſe, you ſhall quickly ſee that,
Command us ſheath our ſwords in one anothers
Boſomes— we'le fly like lightning to execute your
Commands; — you're our Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: No, I'me your Prince's murthreſſe.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: I've kill'd your King: will none
Diſpatch mee yet?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Sure ſhe's diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: We muſt diſarme you Lady; — t'is a duty to our Prince
Was never till now unwillingly perform'd!
You muſt backe to'th Court, whither we'le waite upon you.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Villaines, cowards,

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: The Princeſſe! what made ſhee abroad ſo late?

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: Did ſhe not ſay that ſhee had kill'd the King too?

sp.speaker: Gal:
sp.p: Come let's walke the round; things are yet unſetled.

sp.speaker: Cont.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo darke now, an the divell ſhould lye perdieu I ſhould go neere to ſtumble on's hornes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Too much of this ſad ſtory, Oh theſe men
How are they degenerate from the goodneſſe
Of their creation! they have beene alwaies falſe —

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Silly as we are,
We know it; their vowes and othes are traytours
To us, and yet we hugge them, let them into our boſomes,
Into our hearts, till they undoe us?

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: But Madame, why do'e deſire us to leave you?
Fear you not his fury, what it may prompt him too,
When he ſhall ſee you are not his Calantha.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: He never was acquainted with that paſſion,
He's violent in nothing, — But in love.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And yet he may diſſemble that too
As well as his vowes.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Should hee? were his hand
Lift up to ſtrike mee, I can charme it there!
Who can looke on a Ladies bended knees,
Wet cheekes, ſwolne eyes, heare her ſighs, her prayers,
And yet be cruell: If there be one that can,
That one is not Ferrando; his boſome is
Paſſable to every grone; it ſtrikes his heart:
He would tell mee (when he was abſent)
If I ſigh't, or wept, for then he ſaid
He wept and ſigh'd by ſympathy.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Yet now he loves you not.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.l: Can hee not love himſelfe? here, here I beare him,
Himſelfe in a leſſe modell, this I'le ſhew him,
If he miſtruſt t'is none of his; let him
But rip mee up, there he ſhall ſee each limbe
As like to his, as his one hand, one eye,
One cheeke is like the other: beſides there lyes
Folded by his owne name, he told mee hee
Would call it ſo, (Ferrando,) and leſt I
Should chance forget, I wrote it in my heart,
There he will finde it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Good Lady!

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: T'is a ſad nuptiall night, this,

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: I'le tell him too how hee
Would grieve if I were dead, goe hanging downe
His head, vailing his eyes from heaven, aſham'd
To looke up to the place, where his Felicia is:
Or poring on the ground, as he would finde
Where my neglected aſhes lay a ſport
To th' windes; where ſome rude blaſt might blow mee up
Into his eyes, and then hee'd weepe to finde,
Mee there; weepe till the fretting brine had burn'd
His eye-bals out.
He told mee of his dreames, what pleaſure hee
Had to finde me in 'em: alas they will
Be terrible now: I ſhall affright him, appeare
A thin pale ghoſt, make him ſtart out in his ſleepe;
(Alas! I will not) yet he'le dreame he heard mee.
Cry out, Ferrando! revenge upon Ferrando:
This cannot chuſe but ſtartle him. —

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Heaven grant it may.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.l: Madame all joy that we can hope, or wiſh,
Be with you.

sp.speaker: Fer:—
sp.l: I'le goe alone into the bed-chamber.
There expect him,—pray leave mee.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Good night, I heare him coming.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Our Navie victour.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: The City quiet too I thoſe clouds
Which threatned ruine to your Kingdome, all
Blowne o're; the skie ſerene and calme, as if
It laugh't at your vaine feares; the lampes of heaven
That now ſeem'd all blowne out, are trimm'd a new
And brighter ſhine, to lead you to Elyzium.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: To Heaven, Elyzium's poore to what wee ſhall
Enjoy to night.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: The land of ſome dull villager
Or doughty Poëts dreames.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: The birth of fancie,
A thin, fantaſticke, aierie paradiſe;
With which they flatter their weake hopes, but mine
Is knowne to ſenſe; we gather odours there; wealthy
In their native ſweeteneſſe, flowers of a hew
As bright as laſting, roſes and lillies
Blowne from their ſtalkes, meete here, and dwell upon
Her cheekes, as if there onely they were priviledg'd
To enjoy an everlaſting ſpring. Ʋrſ. Let your
Imaginations ſeed even to a ſurfet, your ſenſes
Are too too weake, and narrow t'entertaine
The bounteous flowing of her pleaſures:
You'le let ſo much paſſe by unknowne,
As if you tooke but tribute of her bleſſings:
When the whole ſtocke is yours.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: We'le be her Mars, and meete her in ſoft skirmiſh,
In amorous duell, where we'le ſoftly yeeld
And let her winne: (to raiſe her to the pride
Of a new victory, as much upon our ſelves
As we have done upon her Country,
Then ſhall ſhee binde us gently in her haire
Fetters for Captive lovers, and in ſcorne
Of our trimme youth, and temperate blood, when we
Begin to faint within her armes, ſhall then
Supply us with new ſtrength from her own eyes;
Whence ſhe will dart a ſoule at every glance
Rich as her ſelfe, and the bleſt ſmiles t'is made of;
Create an active flame within our breaſt
Able to give old ſtatua's life and motion,
Make their ſtiffe marble feete ſupple as the joynts
Of love: — oh I'me loſt! my Venus
Come; lead to my Venus.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: Your Cynthia, —your Moone
sp.stage: Curteine drawne, Feticia diſcovered lying upon a bed, Ziſco▪ as having raviſh't, and then ſlain her.
sp.l: With a man in her—there there's
Your way, why move you not?
How you ſtand.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Ʋrſini, Ha! Se'ſt thou that blacke thing there?
That ugly fiend, I'le out ſtare thee, devill.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: Where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ziſ:
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Raviſh't! Calantha's raviſh't—oh torment!
Grim fury poſt to hell.

sp.speaker: Ziſ:
sp.l: Pardon mee Sir,
I've a little bufineſſe to diſpatch firſt —
This for Felicia, thus Alberto fell.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Oh I'me wounded.

sp.speaker: Ziſ:
sp.p: Ha! do'e know mee Prince?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: Frederico! juſt heavens.

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.l: Stay your hand—be innocent in your revenge,
Let me beare all the guilt.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: Could'ſt thou thinke, dull Prince, that heaven ſo
Doated on thy royaltie, thy crowne, thy ſcepter,
Or regall pall could beare thee out in ſin?
Or the weake ſhine of triviall ſtate dazle
Their eyes that looke upon the bleſſed ſunne!
Could'ſt thou flatter thy ſelfe into ſuch a Security,
That vengeance would not finde thee out?
When thou had'ſt forfeited thy luxurious palate
With all the dainties of Felicia's body
Thirſted her blood, quaff'd off whole bowles of it,
Till thou wer't drunke, and wild with fury
Of thy intemperate draughts —Am not I a rare villaine now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Mad, ſtarke mad, beſides himſelfe,
Sure this is but a dreame, and I aſleepe.

sp.speaker: Ziſ:
sp.p: Thus, thus I'le wake you:—

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: Oh my blood ſcalds, h'has ſhot wild fire into my heart,
Ah traytour, thy ſteele is poyſon'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Frederico, let mee embrace thee:
Now our revenge is perfect.
sp.stage: A noyſe within. Enter fighting, Valenzo, Grutti, Gonçales, Caſſio, Calantha.

sp.speaker: Grut:
sp.p: Your paſſage lyes this way.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: Thorough us.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Treaſon, treaſon, raiſe the Court.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Breake ope the doores.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: We are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Villaine I greete thy heart.

sp.speaker: Caſſ.
sp.p: Where tends your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Slave to hell, and thou ſhalt carry't thither.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Fire, fire, the poyſon boyles my entrals.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: The Prince wounded!

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Where are the traitours?

sp.speaker: Ziſ:
sp.p: Here I am his murtherer.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: Valenzo, I am o'recome. —

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p:
New miracles, Calantha, my beſt my deareſt love: — Oh I am ſicke, ſtand off Calantha, my breath's ſo hot, 'twill ſinge thee elſe; and licke thy beauty's up, like nimble flames;
But doſt thou live?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: To curſe thee falſe and perjur'd.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.l: The ſpheares are out of tune; nature's diſtraught;
The orbes celeſtiall have turn'd round ſo long
That they are giddie: the ſtarres are in a mutiny,
The Intelligences are altogether by'th eares.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Heaven! I bleſſe your juſtice:
Sterne tyrant! that triumph'ſt o're the memory
Of my father, mock'ſt mee with love,
Till like a foole I doated on my fetters,
'Cauſe they were golden ones, that thus
Thy devilliſh art might make my ſoule a captive,
With my body.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Aenigmaticall.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Yet then a Lady mourn'd thy perjur'd vowes.
Whom thou betrayd'ſt to looſe adultery.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Thy ſpeech, Calantha, is darker than an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Truer it is, and dar'ſt thou yet diſſemble it?
'Tis a truth precious to time, who will preſerv't
To blaſt thy memory, and derive a ſtaine
On all thy ſucceſſours.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: How? or when arriv'd this your knowledge Madame?

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.p: How? or when arriv'd this your knowledge Madame?

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Felicia told mee all her ſelfe
Confirm'd it by religious oathes; beſides
This medall which ſhe gave mee from her necke,
A pledge of his broke faith, with the ſad fruits
Of his ſate luſt, within her wombe.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: She's a blacke whore: ſhee lies; beleeve her not.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Thou wilt be damn'd:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So may I; and houle eternally
In thoſe blew flames the devils bath in,
If ever my vowes were made to any other
Then thee; and thoſe, as ſpotleſſe as thy ſoule.—

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: But whom have wee here?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Felicia! Sad Lady ſhe intreated
This night's exchange of place; that ſhe might ſhew him
What an untimely mother he had made her,
And this 'twas caus'd my flight,

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Ha! murder'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: My love.

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.l: My ſiſter! raviſh't:
And murder'd by! mee, inceſtuous villaine!

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Didſt thou not tell mee that Ferrando raviſh't her,
And caſt her to his ſlaves, a prey to their
Bold appetites and furies.

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.l: To incenſe you the more againſt him; I told you
What I onely did imagine, becauſe at my returne
From Sicily, report whiſper'd her loſt,
Loſt in the ruines of my Father,
Which made mee thinke her murder'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.l: Ye Gods! I now acknowledge you ſupreame:
Your power is mighty over our fond arts.
Silly projectours we enſnare our ſelves!
Whilſt we ſpread nets for others.
This braine has wrought all theſe ſad plots,
Calantha, take your Lord; who is as true,
And holy in his vo wes, as thoſe bleſt Saints
He invok't.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: And yet Felicia wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: 'Twas I by whom ſhe ſwell'd, and not Ferrando,
As 'twas ſuppos'd.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Suppos'd! ſhe ſwore 'twas hee.

sp.speaker: Fer:
sp.p: Ʋrſini, farewell; I'le heare the reſt anon—

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: That aggravates my crime, who wrought her into
This falſe beliefe, for having long lov'd her,
Without returne of mutuall flames, and at length
Finding that the impediment was her fond
Dotage upon the Prince; I determin'd,
Rather than not to be poſſeſt of her,
To part with faith and loyaltie, feign'd all
My viſits for him, courted her acceptation
Of his love, which I ſo darkly brought about
That ſhe conſenting to private meetings
As oft as ſhe expected the Prince,
I my ſelfe fill'd her armes.—

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Then you conclude Ferrando innocent▪

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: In act, or thought.

sp.speaker: Ziſ:
sp.l: Felicia! ſiſter! your brother Frederico call's,
She's gon, cold, cold! and pale, and yet methinkes
She ſmiles, looke up, Felicia—

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: But how came it to paſſe ſhe nere diſcry'd you?

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: For reaſons I then gave her: all our meetings
Were in the night, and that i'th darke too, where I
Diſſembled ſo the Prince in voyce and geſture.—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: This agrees right with her relation: villaine thou haſte undone mee.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: And my ſelfe too.

sp.speaker: Ziſc.
sp.p: Death hangs upon her lids, 'tis eternall night with her. hoa, ſiſter, ſtay, take mee along with you; I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pernicious traytour.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Rage choakes my utterance: — give mee your fword.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Our hearts and hands are yours:

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Our hearts and hands are yours:

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Ile be an age in killing thee, do'ſt tremble?
Thou look'ſt like one of thoſe thin frozen ghoſts,
That chattering lye on hils of thicke-ribb'd Ice,
Come meete my fury.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.l: Here, here's my heart.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: I: I'le dig it out,
And caſt it to the hungry fiends.

sp.speaker: Ziſ:
sp.p: My ſtrength decayes, I reele and totter like a crack't reed that leanes againſt the windes.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Take your ſword.—

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ:
sp.p: Madame.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.p: Take it I ſay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You do him too much honour.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Manag't with skill and ſtrength, or thou affront'ſt
My honour,—faint-hearted! coward, I'le follow thee to hell.

sp.speaker: Ʋrſ.
sp.p: Mercy heavens!

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.p: Ho! Charon, more company, lye farther there jolt-head, what quarrelling you dogs? thy oare, thy oare ferriman: clap 'em o'th ſconce with't, there, there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Gods are juſt.

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: You wore their cauſe upon your ſword.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: 'Tis poore revenge this, can he not live againe?
Start up from th'earth with life, and double ſtrength?
Wer't centupled I'de meete him: —but oh my eyes!
Looke here Valenzo: which is Prince, which ſubject,
Which is my lov'd Ferrando? I ſee there is
No ceremonious ſtate, no pompe in death;
They all lye levell, all quiet, the bad as well
As the good, why ſhould this traytour here
This divelliſh arch, arch-traytour lye as ſilent
As his Lord? ſhould he not ſtare, and foame,
Start up and howle, till he wakes all the dead?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Lady:

sp.speaker: Gon:
sp.p: Her old paſſion returnes againe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: —Roare, and curſe heavens,
But they too have forgot to puniſh ſinners,
And reward vertue, here's an example on't;
We were both vertuous, and deſerv'd not this
Bad uſage; let mee embrace thee: —
Cold as the earth he lyes on, and as dull too:
Where is the ſoule, that buſie flame that lent
Him life and motion? affected ſuch vaine pompe
And glorious noyſe: whither is't fled? poore liveleſſe trunke,
It was unkindly done to leave thee thus,
A prey to wormes and rottenneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ziſ.
sp.l: Are you there fury, Megaera, Tiſiphone, Alecto,
Howle, howle, furies, I'le laſh you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Kind death th'art welcome; I kiſſe thy dart.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: The Princeſſe! ſhe's ſlaine, unluckie hand.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Spight of our ſtarres, and all rude oppoſition,
We are one in death: Valenzo ſee us interr'd,
Both in one tombe, that we may mingle aſhes
And be ſecurely lodg'd, you know our ſoules
Were one; our hearts were long united.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A FATALL UNION.

sp.speaker: Cal:
sp.l: Draw, draw the curteines there, my love and I
Muſt ſleepe; — uncivill I proteſt, put out the lights,
We ſhall ſleepe beſt i'th darke; pray don't diſturbe us,
You may fright him from mine armes, —but — I'le — hold — him — faſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The ruin'd treaſure of two Kingdomes
In one heape.

stage.hi: Enter Charintha, Piero, Violetta, Florinda, Alphonſo.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: In the bed-chamber! this way!

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Yes Lady, the cry was full of horrour.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: 'Twas the Phyſitians potion this my Lord.

sp.speaker: Flor:
sp.p: Done in revenge.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.p: Would 'thad bin poyſon.

sp.speaker: Char:
sp.p: Bleſſe mee! whence all theſe tragedies.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment ceizes mee.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: The King:

sp.speaker: Calantha:
sp.p: Ʋrſini dead. ha! whom have we here, Frederico,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, and Felicia too.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: All ſlaine; by what dire hand?

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.l: I'le tell you that within.—
Charintha is your Queene.

sp.speaker: Pier:
sp.p: May you be happy in her love.

sp.speaker: Val:
sp.p: Remove the bodies, i'th morning we will take order for the ſtate, and funerall rites.

lg.l: Of theſe; the laſting ſtory of whoſe wrongs
Shall be all royall lovers evening ſongs.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: AFter theſe ruines, thus your Poët ſtands,
Expecting his owne deſtiny from your hands,
By them he lives or dies; if it ſhould hap
That ſtead of a mild doome, applauſe or clap.
Meete with harſh whiſpers, or halfe ſtifled jeeres,
Such unkinde cenſure kils him; his ſad Muſe
Ʋnleſſe you give her bay, has vow'd to uſe
The Cypreſſe wreathes, her pietie did allow
Thoſe onely to incircle her owne brow:
New life and ſoule to his loſt Poeſie;
His flame's but ſicklie yet, your breath no doubt
Will either blow't up higher, or quite out.
